docs.lead_paragraph: If President Trump resumes his fight with Amazon, the ultimate loser is clear: It will be the American economy.

headline.main: When the President Takes On Amazon, Nobody Wins
headline.print_headline: If the President Takes On Amazon, Nobody Wins

docs.abstract: History is clear: A city that rejects economic opportunity will lose its status as the center of the business world.
docs.snippet: History is clear: A city that rejects economic opportunity will lose its status as the center of the business world.
docs.lead_paragraph: On Nov. 13, 2018, Amazon announced that New York would become one of two locations for the company’s second North American headquarters, ending a competition that had involved more than 200 places, including cities as diverse as Chicago, Atlanta, Denver, Newark and Austin, Tex. But there was hardly any cheering in New York. State Senator Michael Gianaris and other leaders protested that the agreement was bad for New York and bad for its people. They argued that it is absurd for city and state taxpayers to subsidize one of the world’s most valuable companies, owned by the world’s richest man, with as much as $3 billion in taxpayer money.

docs.abstract: Amazon may not call it home. But the city, by design and because of its allure, is increasingly a magnet for coders and companies.
docs.snippet: Amazon may not call it home. But the city, by design and because of its allure, is increasingly a magnet for coders and companies.
docs.lead_paragraph: Euan Robertson started his job with New York City’s economic development team at an ominous moment. It was Monday, Sept. 15, 2008, the day Lehman Brothers filed for bankruptcy and ignited the financial crisis.

headline.main: It Started With a Jolt: How New York Became a Tech Town
headline.print_headline: ‘There was no chance I would go to Mountain View’

docs.abstract: No one knows when the special counsel will file his report on Russian interference in the 2016 election, or whether the public will see it. But two publishers aren’t waiting.
docs.snippet: No one knows when the special counsel will file his report on Russian interference in the 2016 election, or whether the public will see it. But two publishers aren’t waiting.
docs.lead_paragraph: The legions of reporters and commentators following every move by Robert S. Mueller III, the special counsel, do not know when he will finish investigating Russian interference in the 2016 election. And it is unclear whether the report he is expected to file will ever become public.

headline.main: The Mueller Report Is Already a Hit, Sight Unseen
headline.print_headline: Mueller’s Report Is a Hit, Sight Unseen

docs.abstract: It could have answered the concerns of citizens. Instead it bolted.

docs.lead_paragraph: The first word I had that Amazon was about to scrap an agreement to bring 25,000 new jobs to New York City came an hour before it broke in the news on Thursday.

headline.main: Bill de Blasio: The Path Amazon Rejected
